column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2

#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=YOUTH

#Text=This could have occurred nowhere but in England , where men and sea interpenetrate , so to speak -- the sea entering into the life of most men , and the men knowing something or everything about the sea , in the way of amusement , of travel , or of bread-winning .
#Text=We were sitting round a mahogany table that reflected the bottle , the claret-glasses , and our faces as we leaned on our elbows .
#Text=There was a director of companies , an accountant , a lawyer , Marlow , and myself .

#Text=The director had been a Conway boy , the accountant had served four years at sea , the lawyer -- a fine crusted Tory , High Churchman , the best of old fellows , the soul of honour -- had been chief officer in the P. & O. service in the good old days when mail-boats were square-rigged at least on two masts , and used to come down the China Sea before a fair monsoon with stun’-sails set alow and aloft .
#Text=We all began life in the merchant service .

#Text=Between the five of us there was the strong bond of the sea , and also the fellowship of the craft , which no amount of enthusiasm for yachting , cruising , and so on can give , since one is only the amusement of life and the other is life itself .
#Text=Marlow ( at least I think that is how he spelt his name ) told the story , or rather the chronicle , of a voyage :
#Text=“ Yes , I have seen a little of the Eastern seas ; but what I remember best is my first voyage there .
#Text=You fellows know there are those voyages that seem ordered for the illustration of life , that might stand for a symbol of existence .
#Text=You fight , work , sweat , nearly kill yourself , sometimes do kill yourself , trying to accomplish something -- and you ca n’t .
#Text=Not from any fault of yours .
#Text=You simply can do nothing , neither great nor little -- not a thing in the world -- not even marry an old maid , or get a wretched 600-ton cargo of coal to its port of destination .
#Text=“ It was altogether a memorable affair .
#Text=It was my first voyage to the East , and my first voyage as second mate ; it was also my skipper ’s first command .
#Text=You ’ll admit it was time .

#Text=He was sixty if a day ; a little man , with a broad , not very straight back , with bowed shoulders and one leg more bandy than the other , he had that queer twisted-about appearance you see so often in men who work in the fields .

#Text=He had a nut-cracker face -- chin and nose trying to come together over a sunken mouth -- and it was framed in iron-grey fluffy hair , that looked like a chin strap of cotton-wool sprinkled with coal-dust .

#Text=And he had blue eyes in that old face of his , which were amazingly like a boy ’s , with that candid expression some quite common men preserve to the end of their days by a rare internal gift of simplicity of heart and rectitude of soul .
#Text=What induced him to accept me was a wonder .
#Text=I had come out of a crack Australian clipper , where I had been third officer , and he seemed to have a prejudice against crack clippers as aristocratic and high-toned .

#Text=He said to me , ‘ You know , in this ship you will have to work . ’ I said I had to work in every ship I had ever been in . ‘ Ah , but this is different , and you gentlemen out of them big ships ; ... but there ! I dare say you will do .
#Text=Join to-morrow . ’
#Text=“ I joined to-morrow .
#Text=It was twenty-two years ago ; and I was just twenty .
#Text=How time passes !
#Text=It was one of the happiest days of my life .
#Text=Fancy !
#Text=Second mate for the first time -- a really responsible officer ! I would n’t have thrown up my new billet for a fortune .
#Text=The mate looked me over carefully .
#Text=He was also an old chap , but of another stamp .
#Text=He had a Roman nose , a snow-white , long beard , and his name was Mahon , but he insisted that it should be pronounced Mann .
#Text=He was well connected ; yet there was something wrong with his luck , and he had never got on .
#Text=“ As to the captain , he had been for years in coasters , then in the Mediterranean , and last in the West Indian trade .
#Text=He had never been round the Capes .
#Text=He could just write a kind of sketchy hand , and did n’t care for writing at all .
#Text=Both were thorough good seamen of course , and between those two old chaps I felt like a small boy between two grandfathers .
#Text=“ The ship also was old .
#Text=Her name was the Judea .
#Text=Queer name , is n’t it ?
#Text=She belonged to a man Wilmer , Wilcox -- some name like that ; but he has been bankrupt and dead these twenty years or more , and his name do n’t matter .
#Text=She had been laid up in Shadwell basin for ever so long .
#Text=You may imagine her state .
#Text=She was all rust , dust , grime -- soot aloft , dirt on deck .
#Text=To me it was like coming out of a palace into a ruined cottage .
#Text=She was about 400 tons , had a primitive windlass , wooden latches to the doors , not a bit of brass about her , and a big square stern .
#Text=There was on it , below her name in big letters , a lot of scroll work , with the gilt off , and some sort of a coat of arms , with the motto ‘ Do or Die ’ underneath .
#Text=I remember it took my fancy immensely .
#Text=There was a touch of romance in it , something that made me love the old thing -- something that appealed to my youth !
